message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: DiffScene: Diffusion-Based Safety-Critical Scenario Generation for Autonomous Vehicles
Paper Abstract: The field of Autonomous Driving (AD) has witnessed significant progress in recent years. Among the various challenges faced, the safety evaluation of autonomous vehicles (AVs) stands out as a critical concern. Traditional evaluation methods are both costly and inefficient, often requiring extensive driving mileage in order to encounter rare safety-critical scenarios, which are distributed on the long tail of the complex real-world driving landscape. In this paper, we propose a unified approach, Diffusion-Based Safety-Critical Scenario Generation (DiffScene), to generate high-quality safety-critical scenarios which are both realistic and safety-critical for efficient AV evaluation. In particular, we propose a diffusion-based generation framework, leveraging the power of approximating the distribution of low-density spaces for diffusion models. We design several adversarial optimization objectives to guide the diffusion generation under predefined adversarial budgets. These objectives, such as safety-based objective, functionality-based objective, and constraint-based objective, ensure the generation of safety-critical scenarios while adhering to specific constraints. Extensive experimentation has been conducted to validate the efficacy of our approach. Compared with 6 SOTA baselines, DiffScene generates scenarios that are (1) more safety-critical under 3 metrics, (2) more realistic under 5 distance functions, and (3) more transferable to different AV algorithms. In addition, we demonstrate that training AV algorithms with scenarios generated by DiffScene leads to significantly higher performance in terms of the safety-critical metrics compared to baselines. These findings highlight the potential of DiffScene in addressing the challenges of AV safety evaluation, paving the way for safer AV development.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Generative model machine learning":

## Overview

A generative algorithm models how the data was generated in order to categorize a signal, asking the question: based on my generation assumptions, which category is most likely to generate this signal?

## Key Types of Generative Models

With the rise of deep learning, deep generative models (DGMs) formed through the combination of generative models and deep neural networks, with popular examples including variational autoencoders (VAEs), generative adversarial networks (GANs), and auto-regressive models.(no content)A flow-based generative model is a generative model used in machine learning that explicitly models a probability distribution by leveraging normalizing flow.

## Generative vs. Discriminative Models

One of the advantages of generative algorithms is that you can use the joint distribution to generate new data similar to existing data. In contrast, a discriminative algorithm does not care about how the data was generated, it simply categorizes a given signal by learning the conditional probability directly from the data.

## Modern Applications

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data, learning the underlying patterns and structures to produce new data in response to input.

## Key Types of Generative Models

With the rise of deep learning, deep generative models (DGMs) formed through the combination of generative models and deep neural networks, with popular examples including variational autoencoders (VAEs), generative adversarial networks (GANs), and auto-regressive models.(no content)A flow-based generative model is a generative model used in machine learning that explicitly models a probability distribution by leveraging normalizing flow.

## Generative vs. Discriminative Models

One of the advantages of generative algorithms is that you can use the joint distribution to generate new data similar to existing data. In contrast, a discriminative algorithm does not care about how the data was generated, it simply categorizes a given signal by learning the conditional probability directly from the data.

## Modern Applications

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data, learning the underlying patterns and structures to produce new data in response to input.

I've completed a web search for "Autonomous driving." Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car (AC), driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Classification Levels

SAE identified 6 levels for driving automation from level 0 to level 5. These range from Level 0 (no automation) to Level 5 (full autonomy in any conditions).

## Key Companies and Services

**Waymo** is a major player in the space. Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin.(no content)As of December 2025, it operates over 450,000 rides per week.

**Tesla** offers advanced driver assistance features. Tesla Autopilot is an advanced driver-assistance system (ADAS) developed by Tesla, Inc. that provides partial vehicle automation, corresponding to Level 2 automation as defined by SAE International.

**Cruise** (a General Motors subsidiary) has faced challenges. In December 2024, GM stopped funding Cruise.

## Historical Development

The first semi-autonomous car was developed in 1977, by Japan's Tsukuba Mechanical Engineering Laboratory.(no content)In December 2018, Waymo was the first to commercialize a robotaxi service, in Phoenix, Arizona.

The search results provide extensive information about the technology's current state, regulatory landscape, major companies, and development history.

Links: [{"title":"Scenario testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scenario_testing"},{"title":"Interactive Scenario Builder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_Scenario_Builder"},{"title":"Test-driven development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test-driven_development"},{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_testing"},{"title":"Scenario planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scenario_planning"},{"title":"Scenario (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scenario_(computing)"},{"title":"Test case (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_case_(software)"},{"title":"Test plan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_plan"},{"title":"Test suite - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_suite"},{"title":"Scenario (vehicular automation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scenario_(vehicular_automation)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about scenario generation testing:

## Scenario Testing Overview

Scenario testing is a software testing activity that uses scenarios: hypothetical stories to help the tester work through a complex problem or test system.(no content)The ideal scenario test is a credible, complex, compelling or motivating story; the outcome of which is easy to evaluate.

## Key Characteristics

In scenario testing, hypothetical stories are used to help the tester think through a complex problem or system. These scenarios are usually not written down in any detail. They can be as simple as a diagram for a testing environment or they could be a description written in prose.

## Applications in System Development

Since "a system must be evaluated against the specific user tasks it is intended to support", scenarios are ideal for evaluation.(no content)In this method only those sets of realistic, user activities that cover several components in the system are used as scenario tests.

## Different Types of Scenarios

The many forms of scenario written as sequences of steps include Operational Scenarios, Concepts of Operations, and Test Cases. Additionally, Negative scenarios or misuse cases may be written to indicate likely threats which should be countered to ensure that systems have sufficient security, safety, and reliability. These help to discover non-functional requirements.

## Modern Applications

In vehicular automation, Scenarios are created to represent real-world situations and are used for development, testing, and validation purposes.

Links: [{"title":"Adversarial machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_machine_learning"},{"title":"Generative adversarial network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_adversarial_network"},{"title":"Mode collapse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mode_collapse"},{"title":"Search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_search"},{"title":"Adversary model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversary_model"},{"title":"Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning"},{"title":"Robust optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_optimization"},{"title":"Ant colony optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_colony_optimization_algorithms"},{"title":"Adversarial Design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_Design"},{"title":"Advantage (cryptography) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advantage_(cryptography)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of adversarial optimization:

## Adversarial Optimization

Adversarial optimization involves casting optimization into a game, which is different from the usual kind of optimization. This concept appears in multiple contexts within machine learning and computer science:

### In Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
The GAN architecture has two main components, with one being the casting of optimization into a game format, which differs from traditional optimization approaches.(no content)In 1991, Jürgen Schmidhuber published adversarial neural networks that contest with each other in the form of a zero-sum game, where one network's gain is the other network's loss.

### In Malware Detection
Optimization-based attacks such as GAMMA use genetic algorithms to inject benign content into Windows executables, framing evasion as a constrained optimization problem that balances misclassification success with the size of the injected payload.

### In Control Theory
In control theory, adversarial learning based on neural networks was used in 2006 to train robust controllers in a game theoretic sense, by alternating iterations between a minimizer policy (the controller) and a maximizer policy (the disturbance).

The key idea behind adversarial optimization is that two or more entities optimize against each other with competing objectives, creating a dynamic where improvement by one party may require adaptation by the other.

The GAN architecture has two main components, with one being the casting of optimization into a game format, which differs from traditional optimization approaches.(no content)In 1991, Jürgen Schmidhuber published adversarial neural networks that contest with each other in the form of a zero-sum game, where one network's gain is the other network's loss.

### In Malware Detection
Optimization-based attacks such as GAMMA use genetic algorithms to inject benign content into Windows executables, framing evasion as a constrained optimization problem that balances misclassification success with the size of the injected payload.

### In Control Theory
In control theory, adversarial learning based on neural networks was used in 2006 to train robust controllers in a game theoretic sense, by alternating iterations between a minimizer policy (the controller) and a maximizer policy (the disturbance).

The key idea behind adversarial optimization is that two or more entities optimize against each other with competing objectives, creating a dynamic where improvement by one party may require adaptation by the other.

Web search results for query: "Safety validation testing"

Links: [{"title":"Software verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Engineering validation test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering_validation_test"},{"title":"Electrical safety testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_safety_testing"},{"title":"Field sobriety testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_Sobriety_Test"},{"title":"ISO 13849 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_13849"},{"title":"Conformance testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conformance_testing"},{"title":"Hardware stress test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware_stress_test"},{"title":"Validation (drug manufacture) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validation_(drug_manufacture)"},{"title":"Safety engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of safety validation testing:

## Definition

Independent Software Verification and Validation (ISVV) is targeted at safety-critical software systems and aims to increase the quality of software products, thereby reducing risks and costs throughout the operational life of the software, with the goal of providing assurance that software performs to the specified level of confidence and within its designed parameters and defined requirements.

## Key Characteristics

ISVV activities are performed by independent engineering teams, not involved in the software development process, to assess the processes and the resulting products.(no content)While traditional verification and validation aim to ensure that software performs well against nominal requirements, ISVV is focused on non-functional requirements such as robustness and reliability.

## Standards and Frameworks

ISO 13849-2, Part 2: Validation, specifies the procedures to be followed for validating by analysis or tests, the safety functions of the system, the category achieved and the performance level achieved. Additionally, safety guidelines typically prescribe a set of steps, deliverable documents, and exit criterion focused around planning, analysis and design, implementation, verification and validation, configuration management, and quality assurance activities for the development of a safety-critical system.

## Testing Methods

ISO 13849-2 includes all of the details required for validation using analytical techniques (including FMEA, FMECA, FMEDA, IFA SISTEMA or any of the other analytical tools available), functional testing, and documentation in a validation record.

Web search results for query: "Diffusion model"

Links: [{"title":"Diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_model"},{"title":"Bass diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bass_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Latent diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Stable Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion"},{"title":"Text-to-image model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-image_model"},{"title":"Demic diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demic_diffusion"},{"title":"NovelAI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NovelAI"},{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_model"},{"title":"DALL-E - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DALL-E"},{"title":"Midjourney - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midjourney"}]

## Diffusion Model

A **diffusion model** is a type of machine learning model with important applications in generative AI. Here are the key aspects:

### Definition and Structure

In machine learning, diffusion models, also known as diffusion-based generative models or score-based generative models, are a class of latent variable generative models.(no content)A diffusion model consists of two major components: the forward diffusion process, and the reverse sampling process.(no content)A diffusion model models data as generated by a diffusion process, whereby a new datum performs a random walk with drift through the space of all possible data.

### Purpose and Goal

The goal of diffusion models is to learn a diffusion process for a given dataset, such that the process can generate new elements that are distributed similarly as the original dataset.

### How They Work

These typically involve training a neural network to sequentially denoise images blurred with Gaussian noise. The model is trained to reverse the process of adding noise to an image. After training to convergence, it can be used for image generation by starting with an image composed of random noise, and applying the network iteratively to denoise the image.

### Applications

As of 2024, diffusion models are mainly used for computer vision tasks, including image denoising, inpainting, super-resolution, image generation, and video generation.(no content)Other than computer vision, diffusion models have also found applications in natural language processing such as text generation and summarization, sound generation, and reinforcement learning.

### Notable Examples

Diffusion-based image generators have seen widespread commercial interest, such as Stable Diffusion and DALL-E.

### History

Diffusion models were introduced in 2015 as a method to train a model that can sample from a highly complex probability distribution. They used techniques from non-equilibrium thermodynamics, especially diffusion.
